awd_abstract_narration:
Mutations in genes affect their function in many different ways. There are thousands of genes in the genome of any organism, so it is a major challenge to decipher the role of each gene. The focus of this project is to build a new and more efficient technology platform that will enable researchers to efficiently understand how mutations in a gene affect the function encoded by that gene. This platform which uses the tools of synthetic biology will allow researchers to develop such understanding much more rapidly. Such efforts are central to a broad range of applications in both applied and basic science. It may help with the development of new strains for the production of pharmaceutical proteins, enzymes, chemicals, or fuels. It will also help to develop forward engineering paradigms central to the future of bioengineering. In the development of this platform, the investigators will also train multiple graduate and undergraduate students in cutting edge science, technology, engineering and mathematical (STEM) approaches and technologies.  These students will develop expertise in experimental and computational methods, the design, execution, and reporting of scientific research, and the generation of intellectual property. 

A fundamental goal of synthetic biology is to develop new paradigms for the forward engineering of biological systems. The prototypical forward engineering process involves design, build, test, and learn (DBTL) stages, which ideally are performed in a cyclical and highly parallel fashion leading to the build up of knowledge bases, codified design rules, and optimized designs. In biological endeavors, the "DBTL" strategy has historically been realized through "sequence to activity relationship (SAR)" mutational mapping, which has traditionally been limited in throughput to addressing only the smallest of biological systems. Advances in DNA synthesis and sequencing technologies however, have paved the way for new massively parallel approaches to SAR that extend to the genome scale. Several technologies that have been developed will be optimized in a generally accessible framework for use by the larger synthetic biology community.  Such a framework will enable new forward DBTL-type engineering strategies at scales that are orders of magnitude more advanced than methods currently available. The investigators in this project have chosen to focus their efforts on the comprehensive mapping of gene essentiality in the model bacterium Escherichia coli because this model system is not only ideal for demonstrating their platform but also will allow them to address foundational questions concerning essentiality, evolvability, epistasis and fitness. This will have broad implications across genetics, synthetic biology and biotechnology.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
This project had two ambitious goals: empirically map the sequence-to-function (S2F) relationship of each amino acid in E. coli proteins known to be essential for survival and develop a method to recursively mutate these genes such that a cell would contain multiple mutations of interest in the same or different genes.

We successfully generated S2F data for the majority (~75%) of 84,292 amino acids across 248 essential genes. While the vast majority of these amino acids have never been functionally evaluated before, our dataset also found residues that had been previously reported as essential, such as the lysine in position 156 in threonine--tRNA ligase or the aspartate residue in position 36 in DNA ligase; as our dataset contains these previously known residues along with others, this strengthens our confidence that the dataset represent real empirical measurements of function. Additionally, the construction of this library was successfully repeated twice, further supporting the validity of this dataset. Finally, we validated six individual designs which our dataset had identified as essential. Two of these designs are the previously mentioned lysine in position 156 in threonine--tRNA ligase and the aspartate in position 36 in DNA ligase, while two residues designated as essential were picked nearby. Five of the six designs were shown to be lethal to varying degrees, indicating their essentiality for life; the one non-lethal design conveyed a severe growth defect to the cell, which could indicate a less-severely compromised protein or a function that is required for growth but not survival.

Unfortunately, we were unable to produce a planned site saturation library that would mutate key residues of interest to every other possible amino acid. We were also unable to develop a method of recursive editing, though efforts were made to evaluate potential methods. Initial experiments produced ambiguous results towards the viability of the approach, but time constraints only allowed for two repetitions of this initial work.

 


Last Modified: 12/12/2022
Modified by: William G Alexander

Images (1 of )
  • Selection of alanine scanning library in rich media yields essential residues in E. coli DNA ligase. Residues chosen for validation are shown as green squares and labeled.
    William G. Alexander
    Creative Commons
    William G Alexander
    Essentiality Plot of ligA
  • Selection of alanine scanning library in rich media yields essential residues in E. coli threonine--tRNA ligase. Residues chosen for validation are shown as green squares and labeled.
    William G. Alexander
    Creative Commons
    William G Alexander
    Essentiality Plot of thrS
  • The previously described mutation D36A, along with nearby residues P28A and E44A, all exhibit high lethality when evaluated in singleton.
    William G. Alexander & Eun Oh
    Creative Commons
    William G Alexander
    Selected ligA designs exhibit high lethality
  • A) Only the previously described mutation K156A exhibited a strong lethal phenotype; L160A was mildly lethal, while E153A exhibited no lethality. B) However, E153A mutants exhibited a growth defect in rich media at 37 C.
    William G. Alexander & Eun Oh
    Creative Commons
    William G Alexander
    Selected thrS designs validate in singleton

This project had two ambitious goals: empirically map the sequence-to-function (S2F) relationship of each amino acid in E. coli proteins known to be essential for survival and develop a method to recursively mutate these genes such that a cell would contain multiple mutations of interest in the same or different genes.

Finally, we validated six individual designs which our dataset had identified as essential. Two of these designs are the previously mentioned lysine in position 156 in threonine--tRNA ligase and the aspartate in position 36 in DNA ligase, while two residues designated as essential were picked nearby. Initial experiments produced ambiguous results towards the viability of the approach, but time constraints only allowed for two repetitions of this initial work.
